snippet.title: David Chase Nashville Defamation Lawsuit Deposition
snippet.description:
NASHVILLE, TN (WSMV) - Video deposition of David Chase, obtained by the Channel 4 I-Team, shows the embattled hotel developer criticizing the district attorney and the woman who accused him of domestic violence, while discussing his own troubled past.

Another court filing also shows Chase asked for, and received, a change in his bond conditions that allowed him to remove the interlock device in his car.

Chase’s attorney writes in the filing that Chase wants to become an Uber driver.

Chase became a familiar name in middle Tennessee in 2014 after he was charged with domestic violence and was then allowed by a judge to avoid a 12-hour cooling off period after his arrest.

After that charge was ultimately dropped, Chase then filed a civil lawsuit in Williamson County, suing nine people, including Chase’s ex-girlfriend who brought the criminal charge against him.

When asked what the DA’s office could have done different, Chase replied, “Any level of investigation at all, period. Which they didn’t do any.”

Chase claims after the criminal charge, his reputation was damaged. He suffered humiliation and millions of dollars in financial loss because he said the ex-girlfriend he is accused of attacking conspired with another former girlfriend and others to ruin him.

“She stalked, harassed, trespassed, assaulted me and made false allegations that had me falsely imprisoned,” Chase said.

“She denies that she assaulted him,” said Rob McGuire, who represents Chase’s ex-girlfriend. “She denies that she entered into this conspiracy to defame him or ruin him. The truth of the matter is she’s a domestic violence victim.”

In the deposition, attorney Brian Manookian, who represents some of the others being sued, grilled Chase about his past. He asked how someone’s reputation can be damaged if their reputation is already questionable.

“Just tell me, how many times do you think you’ve been charged with assault, regardless of who charged you?” Manookian asked. “And keep going down this list, including the DUIs.”

“Five,” Chase replied.

“Do gentlemen take molly, snort cocaine, hang out in strip clubs and date strippers?” Manookian asked.

“I’m not sure,” Chase said. “Sure some do.”

“You would be one of those types of gentlemen, wouldn’t you, Mr. Chase?” Manookian said.

“Apparently so,” Chase said.

In the deposition, Chase said he is currently unemployed.

Chase’s attorney spoke to Channel 4 Thursday. He said the deposition did not tell Chase’s whole story and he hopes to get justice through the suit.

Chase’s request to remove the interlock device was approved. It is unclear if he is currently working as an Uber driver.
